Thanks. @fdncred .

candidates.title: fix some misalignment errors
candidates.body:
This fixes errors like this one, where one of the columns is misaligned
```
sys | get host
───┬─────────┬──────────┬───────────────┬───────────────────────┬────────────────
 # │  name   │ version  │   hostname    │        uptime         │    sessions
───┼─────────┼──────────┼───────────────┼───────────────────────┼────────────────
 0 │ Windows │ 6.2.9200 │ SOMEHOSTNAME │ 8day 23hr 13min 46sec │ [table 5 rows]
───┴─────────┴──────────┴───────────────┴───────────────────────┴────────────────
```
What I found was that some strings ended with a c style null string `\0`, so I wrapped all string returns with a function to remove that.

candidates.title: Temporarily(?) switch from heim+uom to sysinfo
candidates.body:
This moves us onto using sysinfo instead of heim+uom. There are a few changes as a result:

* There aren't 1:1 equivalents for heim in sysinfo, which means some of the features we used to have aren't supported. Notably now missing: battery info, some of the system info fields, and maybe 1(?) of the ps fields.

* The reported processor memory usage differs. I noticed that current `nu` also differs from other process monitor tools I use, so perhaps different apps just count sizes differently.

* We also lose the fancy `benchmark` output because it relied on uom.

Performance between the two seems relatively similar.

Compile times improve noticeably. Here's a before/after `cargo bloat` run (in total, a `cargo build --all --features=extra` build drops from 5 mins 30 sec to 5 mins for me):

## Before
```
  Time Crate
61.78s nu_command
40.93s uom
 9.85s syn
 8.95s nu_engine
 8.10s nu
 7.59s clap
```
## After 
```
  Time Crate
72.37s nu_command
10.75s nu_engine
10.61s syn
 8.65s nu_protocol
 8.54s clap
 8.42s nu
 8.31s nu_plugin
```

candidates.title: working for comparing filepath to string
candidates.body:
I think this fixes the `in` `not-in` command. Here are two tests that I fixed.

```
echo '[{"name": "foo", "size": 3}, {"name": "foo", "size": 2}, {"name": "bar", "size": 4}]' | from json | where size in [2]
```
and
```
ls | where name in ['src', 'README.md']
```

candidates.title: Feature/def signature with comments
candidates.body:
This commit applied changes how the signature of a function is parsed. Before
there was a little bit of "quick-and-dirty" string-matching/parsing involved.
Now, a signature is a little bit more properly parsed.
The grammar of a definition signature understood by these parsing-functions is
as follows:
 `[ (parameter | flag | <eol>)* ]`
where
parameter is:
    `name (<:> type)? (<,> | <eol> | (#Comment <eol>))?`
flag is:
    `--name (-shortform)? (<:> type)? (<,> | <eol> | (#Comment <eol>))?`
(Note: After the last item no <,> has to come.)
Note: It is now possible to pass comments to flags and parameters
Example:
```shell
> def x [
hello :int # First message
world: string # Second message
--lit : path # My list flag :)
] { echo hello world }

> x -h


Usage:
  > x <hello> <world> {flags} 

Parameters:
  <hello> First message
  <world> Second message

Flags:
  -h, --help: Display this help message
  --lit <file path>: My list flag :)

```

(Sadly there seems to be a bug (Or is this expected behaviour?) in the lexer, because of which `--x(-x)` would
be treated as one baseline token and is therefore not correctly recognized as 2. For
now a space has to be inserted)

During the implementation of the module, a question arose:
Should flag/parameter names be allowed to be type names?
Example case:
```shell
def f [ string ] { echo $string }
```
Currently an error is thrown

candidates.title: Split nu-cli into nu-cli/nu-engine
candidates.body:
We split off the evaluation engine part of nu-cli into its own crate. This helps improve build times for nu-cli by 17% in my tests. It also helps us see a bit better what's the core engine portion vs the part specific to the interactive CLI piece.

There's more than can be done here, but I think it's a good start in the right direction.

candidates.title: Update dependency rust-embed now that issue with its use of syn has been fixed.
candidates.body: I brought the `syn` issue to the attention of the `rust-embed` folks who fixed the issue in `rust-embed-impl`. See https://github.com/pyros2097/rust-embed/commit/05b1f43cbb7d626f0c55d9531c33dd8078d218f6 for the changes that were made for `rust-embed` version 5.8.0 that mean that `nu` no longer needs to pin the version of syn.

candidates.title: Replace `clipboard` with `arboard`
candidates.body:
Replaces the unmaintained `clipboard` crate with `arboard`.

It seemed to me that the [`Value`](https://docs.rs/nu-protocol/0.24.1/nu_protocol/value/struct.Value.html) type doesn't have a standard image format, but if it does, that could also be placed to the clipbard using `arboard`.

candidates.title: remove code not used. Fix use shadow-rs build warning
Multiline scripts part 2
candidates.body:
Okay, this is the big one.

This adds:

* Variables

```
set x = 1 + 3
```

* Custom commands

```
def foo [x y] {
  = $x + $y
}
```

alternatively:

```
def foo [x:int y:int] {
  = $x + $y
}
```
(`:any` is implied)

* Replacement-style aliases

```
alias ll = ls -l
ll -a
```

Note: aliases only work on commands, not pipelines. So you currently can't alias to a pipeline, only a single command

* Comments:

```
# this is now a comment
do thing
```

```
do other-thing  # this should also be a comment
```

* Some bugfixes where I could find them
* Probably some fun new bugs
* A different way of doing scope. I strongly suspect there are some bugs hidden here that will be fixed once we finish proper scope closures. Until then, apologies in advance :sweat_smile: 
* I had to comment out the alias type inference. We should definitely add this back where it makes sense.
* I commented out a couple of the autoenv tests. We should also revisit these. There was something a bit odd about how things got set and reset as you leave directories, but I couldn't figure it out.
* Probably stuff I'm forgetting

candidates.title: highlight trailing spaces in tables in darkgray
candidates.body:
This PR highlights leading & trailing spaces in tables so that they're easier to see. I've been burnt several times trying to parse things only to find out later that the reason I couldn't parse things properly was because there were trailing spaces.

Trailing Spaces Example
`cargo search nu_plugin --limit 24 | lines | parse "{crate_name} = {version} #{description}" | skip 1`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/343840/102406417-2572b300-3fb0-11eb-8859-faa2da7fea71.png)

Leading Spaces Example
`cargo search nu_plugin --limit 24 | lines | parse "{crate_name} ={version} #{description}" | skip 1`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/343840/102502346-1e958000-4044-11eb-8195-d486644a0b76.png)

The color of the white space indicator is controlled by `leading_trailing_space_bg` in the `[color_config]` section of the `config.toml`
